awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award support computational research aimed at understanding the superconducting mechanisms of a class of doped high temperature superconductors, namely the two dimensional compound LiHfNCl and the three dimensional insulator BaKBiO3 that superconduct in the 25-30 K temperature range.  Unlike low-temperature heavy fermion superconductors or the high temperature superconducting cuprates and iron pnictides, in which there is strong magnetic behavior near and within the superconducting state and a majority of researchers expect the pairing mechanism to involve magnetism, this class of doped-insulator high temperature superconductors do not contain any magnetic ions, and the electron-phonon coupling is too weak to account for their high critical temperatures. 
 
This project addresses the situation that arises in such materials where a relatively low density of doped carriers interact dynamically within a background of highly charged moving ions. The effective electron-electron interaction is screened both by other electrons and by the moving ions.  The conventional means of handling screening, via the random phase approximation, is insufficient, as it misses important short-range correlations resulting from weak short-range screening of strong interactions, and gives an overall weak coupling. The theoretical approach will be to extend the treatment of the dielectric screening matrix beyond the mean field, thereby coupling the screening process of the ions and the carriers. The potential payoff for these investigations is a detailed understanding of a new pairing mechanism that produces superconductivity at 30 K and might be a good candidate to produce substantially higher critical temperatures.

An important outcome of this research that could have a societal impact through sustainable green-energy is the potential discovery and design of new superconductors. This award also supports the education of a graduate student and a postdoctoral research associate at the frontiers of computational condensed matter physics, and will contribute to the training of young scientists who will form tomorrow's scientific and technological workforce.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award support computational research aimed at understanding how a class of materials with composition LiHfNCl and BaKBiO3, which do not normally conduct electricity, enter a phase at low temperatures wherein electricity flows through them without any resistance, making them superconductors.  Unlike some of the more commonly known superconductors in which the strong interaction of the electrons with the vibrations of the positively charged nuclei are ultimately responsible for their superconducting properties, the electron-nuclei interaction in these materials is not strong enough to account for the observed temperatures at which they become superconducting. 

Understanding the newest and most exotic superconductors remains at the intellectual frontier of condensed matter theory. In this project, the PI and his group will develop the theory and perform the necessary large-scale computations to treat dynamical behavior of electrons as they interact with each other and with highly charged moving ions with the ultimate goal of capturing the essential mechanism through which these materials become superconducting. 

An important outcome of this research that could have a societal impact through sustainable green-energy is the potential discovery and design of new superconductors. This award also supports the education of a graduate student and a postdoctoral research associate at the frontiers of computational condensed matter physics, and will contribute to the training of young scientists who will form tomorrow's scientific and technological workforce.

We begin with the intellectual merit. As the title indicates, the project has conducted research into several types of electron pairing in doped insulators.

The year 2015 introduced a new record high temperature superconductor (from a German group) at 200 K, a temperature that has been reported on the surface of the earth (Antarctica). This project has provided theoretical analysis in two publications of the character and strength of the coupling of electrons with atomic vibrations that enables the superconducting phase. This new superconductor hydrogen sulfide (H3S), with a remarkably simple, cubic crystal structure (figure provided), has peculiar aspects of its electronic structure that promotes useful electronic interactions. A figure of the "Fermi surfaces" of H3S is provided, the superconducting electrons lie on these surfaces.

A class of two-dimensional doped insulators (viz. Li-doped ZrNCl) has been studied for its inter-electronic interactions. The mechanism of superconducting pairing in this class of materials remains a mystery; it is not magnetic and the conventional treatment of electron pairing by atomic vibrations does not explain data.  This project addressed two means of doping charge carriers into the bialyer of highly charged ions: Zr(4+), N(3-). Both types lead to the same superconducting state, but we have shown that there are large differences in the electronic properties besides superconductivity. This class of superconductors remains an enigma.

  A strongly interacting model of electrons on a square lattice of atoms (the popular Hubbard model) with 1/5 of the sites removed provides a means to study one class of the iron-based superconductors [Fe(4)Se(5)] as well as an unusual magnetic insulator CaV(4)O(9). This project studied the superconducting pairing corrrelations, finding a connection to the nearby (in the phase diagram, figure provided) magnetic phase. These resullts, based on quantum Monte Carlo methods, merited publication in a high profile journal.

An unusual niobium suboxide Nb(12)O(29) has, from charge counting, two "free" electrons per formula unit, and experiment shows that one in localized and magnetic while the other provides electronic conduction. This project  provided a microscopic picture of how this can and does happen. This material is a two dimensional system with spin chains and conducting paths running in perpendicular directions (schematic figure provided).

Insulating FeGa3 poses peculiar puzzles beyond the occurrence of an electronic gap in an intermetallic Fe+Ga compound. This Fe-based material has a very distinctive structural characteristic:  Fe sites occurring in dimers, making the Fe-Fe electronic and magnetic interaction a dominant feature. Density functional theory methods have been applied to follow the evolution of the magnetic properties and electronic spectrum with doping, where unusual behavior is observed experimentally. Both electron and hole carrier doping were studied, by Ge and Zn on the Ga site, and by Co and Mn on the Fe site. A figure of the "hole density" and "electron density" is provided.The former changes only the bystander Ga sites, while the latter introduces direct disturbance of the Fe2 dimer. Results from weakly and strongly correlated modeling of the electronic system were compared and contrasted. Regardless of the method that was used, magnetism including itinerant phases appears readily with doping. The picture in which interactions between the two Fe sites are strong suggests that in the low doping limit Mn (for Fe) produces an in-gap hole state, while Co (for Fe) introduces a localized electronic gap state.
